docs.lead_paragraph: An analysis of 43 popular wellness apps by the nonprofit Privacy Rights Clearinghouse found that many apps connect to advertising and data-analysis sites without the user’s knowledge.

headline.main: Free Apps for Nearly Every Health Problem, but What About Privacy?
headline.print_headline:
In Health Apps,
Lots of Information,
But Not Much Privacy

docs.abstract: Ann Carrns Your Money Adviser column; notes analysis of 43 popular wellness apps by nonprofit Privacy Rights Clearinghouse finds that many apps connect to advertising and data-analysis sites without user’s knowledge; says apps can be useful in providing information and motivation, but warns privacy is not priority.
docs.snippet: An analysis of 43 popular wellness apps by the nonprofit Privacy Rights Clearinghouse found that many apps connect to advertising and data-analysis sites without the user’s knowledge.

docs.lead_paragraph: Much progress has been made in the campaign to reduce mortality by 2015, but many gaps still remain.

headline.main: The Race to Improve Global Health
headline.print_headline: The Race to Improve Global Health

docs.abstract: Editorial warns that without more intense efforts and money the world will not meet the United Nations' Millennium Development goals to reduce mortality by 2015; observes that while much progress has been made, there are significant gaps, such as providing antiviral therapy to all people infected with HIV and in distributing low-cost remedies for common causes of death like malaria.
docs.snippet: Much progress has been made in the campaign to reduce mortality by 2015, but many gaps still remain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Clinics are popping up offering unproven treatment for a price, posing a challenge for scientists who are moving cautiously and seeking more data.

headline.print_headline: Ill, Desperate And in Search Of Stem Cells

docs.abstract: Stem cell clinics in United States and Mexico, like Regenerative Medicine Institute in Tijuana, are offering unproven stem cell treatments for high price to desperate clients, posing challenge for scientists who are moving cautiously and seeking more data; efficacy and safety of such treatments remains in question.
docs.snippet: Clinics are popping up offering unproven treatment for a price, posing a challenge for scientists who are moving cautiously and seeking more data.

keywords.value: International Society for Stem Cell Research
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Respirator masks, used by responders after the 9/11 attacks, played a role in exposing thousands to contaminated air, but the government and the hazardous-equipment industry are trying for better.

headline.main: Improving Respirator Masks to Put Fresh Air in Reach

docs.abstract: Poorly functioning respirator masks used by workers at ground zero after September 11 attacks played role in exposing thousands to contaminated air; government and hazardous-equipment industry are together working to create new generation of respirator masks to be used by rescue and cleanup workers and also to protect against potential disease outbreaks or releases of nanoparticles.
docs.snippet: Respirator masks, used by responders after the 9/11 attacks, played a role in exposing thousands to contaminated air, but the government and the hazardous-equipment industry are trying for better.

docs.lead_paragraph: Honors for developers of cochlear implants, neuroscientists studying neural transmissions, and Bill and Melinda Gates, for their work in promoting global health.

headline.main: Lasker Awards Go to Five Scientists and Gateses

docs.abstract: Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation announces recipients of its 2013 awards in clinical medical research, basic medical research and public service.
docs.snippet: Honors for developers of cochlear implants, neuroscientists studying neural transmissions, and Bill and Melinda Gates, for their work in promoting global health.

docs.lead_paragraph: A combination of two well-known antiviral drugs could potentially save humans from MERS, or Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, scientists said Sunday.

headline.main: Drug Cocktail That Protects Monkeys From Deadly Virus May Aid Humans
headline.print_headline: Drug Cocktail That Protects Monkeys From Deadly Virus May Aid Humans

docs.abstract: Researchers at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases say that a combination of well-known antiviral drugs ribavirin and interferon protects monkeys against MERS and could potentially be used to save humans from the lethal disease; study on the use of the drugs in monkeys will be published in journal Nature Medicine.
docs.snippet: A combination of two well-known antiviral drugs could potentially save humans from MERS, or Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, scientists said Sunday.

keywords.value: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: MAYER--Lloyd F., MD -- It is with profound sadness that we at The Mount Sinai Medical Center mark the passing of our cherished friend and outstanding colleague, Lloyd F. Mayer, MD. Dr. Mayer graduated from the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in 1976 and received the Mosby Award for Clinical Excellence at that time. It was one of many awards he would receive for a lifetime of outstanding work, including the Saul Horowitz Award and the Irma T. Hirschl Trust Career Development Award, the Jeffrey Modell Foundation Lifetime Achievement Award, the Jaffe Food Allergy Institute Award for Scientific Excellence, and the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America (CCFA) Scientific Achievement Award. Dr. Mayer's interdisciplinary and internationally renowned laboratory focused on mucosal immunoregulation, inflammatory bowel diseases, and cytokine regulation of human B-cell differentiation. He and his team were the first to show that the epithelial lining cells of the intestine are active regulators of mucosal immune responses that are distinct from those that regulate systemic immunity. These findings had a profound significance in the development of highly effective anti-inflammatory drugs for IBD. Dr. Mayer, with support from The Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust, launched the IBD Center at Mount Sinai as well as established a national network of academic medical institutions for collaborative basic research in IBD. From 1980 through 1984, Dr. Mayer held joint appointments at Rockefeller University and Mount Sinai. In 1986, he was named the Chief of the Division of Clinical Immunology at Mount Sinai, and in 1990 he became Vice Chair of Medicine. Dr. Mayer was named the David and Dorothy Merksamer Professor of Medicine in 1994, and three years later, he became Professor of Immunobiology and Chair of the Immunobiology Center. He served as Chief of the Division of Gastroenterology from 2003 to 2010, and in 2007 he became Professor and Co-Director of the Immunology Institute. From 2008-2012, Dr. Mayer was also Chairman of the National Scientific Advisory Committee of the CCFA. Dr. Mayer spoke and published widely, and his research was consistently funded by the National Institutes of Health. He also leaves behind multiple generations of physicians who trained with and were mentored by him. We at Mount Sinai, and the scientific community at large, feel a tremendous loss at his death. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Dr. Jill Fishbane-Mayer, their three children, Sara, Marisa and Josh, as well as Dr. Mayer's extended family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; and Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

docs.lead_paragraph: Paul Kagame is an international hero for reforming Rwanda. But cleaning up a country doesn’t come without moral hazards.
docs.abstract: Profile of Rwandan Pres Paul Kagame, whose successful efforts to reform his ravaged country have been tainted by his authoritarian tendencies.
docs.snippet: Paul Kagame is an international hero for reforming Rwanda. But cleaning up a country doesn’t come without moral hazards.
